comment:
This game is straight up garbage.
Chess is garbage. It has no real theme, no depth of story, nothing that's visually pleasing to look at, it's limited to exactly two players, it feels really slow and can end up in a pointless dead-end where none of the players can win, and it's designed in a way where the most experienced player will win more or less Every. Single. Time. It's a game of experience and pattern recognition that strongly benefits those who've spent the most time learning every move. If you've played it more than your opponent has, you probably win, and losing in a game of chess feels painfully boring. That's a reeeeally poor concept of a game!

There's no reason for anyone to play chess still in this day and age where there's literally THOUSANDS of better games, the only ones who actually finds chess interesting to play are:

A. Those playing chess for nostalgic reasons. They played it as a kid because our parents and grandparents tricked us in to playing it.

B. Those who are desperate to join the large chess community for their own social needs. Chess have fooled millions and millions of ordinary people to play the game, making it a massive community that's quite appealing to become a part of. You wouldn't ever even consider playing chess if there were eight active players worldwide and if chess had the same level of publicity as my grandmas interest in sudoku, let's be honest.

C. It's one of the only board games you've heard of. You've heard of it a billion times with a million different references, because it has existed since the 1400's when they had no inspiration and no creativity in terms of creating a fun activity to enjoy in their spare time. This abomination was the result of that. And you fell in the trap of becoming invested in chess because of its undeserved status. It's an iconic board game for the sole reason that we had nothing to compete with it for a thousand terrible years.

D. You (wrongfully) believe that playing and understanding chess is a sign of intelligence. This has been disproven countless of times and we now know that a person's intellectual level has little to barely any impact on your ability to play- and win a game of chess. A low intellectual with years of experience and who've learned most of the patterns and moves in chess will defeat an ultra-intellectual genius more or less every time in chess, if the genius have only played chess a few times. Chess is a sign of lacking character and not a sign of intelligence.

E. You are generally fascinated by boring/uninteresting activities and your personality fits perfectly for a game of chess.

F. All of the above.

I want us all to join up and turn against this dreadfully dreary piece of trash and move on. We have over these last 20 years entered a revolutionary era of genuinely fun, interesting, well-made and meaningful board games that are brilliantly designed both thematically and in terms of gameplay, and these modern games needs to take over the spotlight from the old boring relics such as chess.
Abstract strategy, not my type.

I remember the moment I lost interest in this: me and a friend were playing it for fun, and then neither of us could move. We asked his dad, and he said it was a stalemate, nobody won. Well, never playing that again!

In hindsight, the pieces are made way too strong in this version, which ironically makes moving around the board difficult (because it's easy to defend and turtle). So there's more stalemates and standoffs compared to eastern versions of Chess. Not to mention the cultural heritage where it's THINKY AND QUIET instead of a rowdy street game, hrmm.

Ugh. I wish I could get back those wasted hours of tedium and frustration.

Since I've started recording games on the geek: 1660-1088=102.


Update: finally played a tournament for the first time this year (2011) since 1998. Looking forward to getting back into competition. 

Return to tournament play has been good although I did sink down in rating  but broke even for 2011 going +4-4=1 for the year. 

2012 has started out well but had a weak finish. So the year ended with me going +12-11=4 in tournament play. Cracked 1500 level for the first time rating wise!!!   Very happy about that! The year ended badly with two disastrous tournaments. I won only 1 game in my last 9   Hopefully 2013 will be better. 

2013 is off to a terrific start! I finished second in the 1400-1499 group in the U1700 section of the Land of the Sky XXVI tournament in Asheville, NC. I also finished second in the U1800 section for the Saturday morning blitz tournament. As a result, I now have my highest rating ever at 1516!  Finished the Pittsburgh Open with my new highest rating ever of 1589 and another tie for 2nd in my class. I didn't play another tournament this year but I did well and hope for some tournaments in 2014. So I finished 2013 +9-7=3.

First tournament of 2016 was blitz tournament at the VA Closed. First play since 2013 resulted in a bad showing of 3/8.
So far for 2016 +3-5.

The winner is usually determined before the game starts, based on the players skill (and this from someone that would probably beat 95% of the people in the world if I played them).

For the game, I'd give 5. Fact is that chess outcome is always draw (if players are equal). The winning - losing difference comes from the fact that one side, or other did not scan through (or forgot, while dying in boredom) all information about established moves/counter moves.

Every once and a while, one manages to beat decent chess player by doing something unexpected and borderline ridiculous. In these occasions game can momentarily be fun before player who deviated from The True Way(tm) is quickly beaten to death by community that does not allow anyone to deviate from the Established Truth and Scripture(tm). Hence, due to players being what they are, rating is 2.

In any case, Shogi is much, much better game of this genre.

Chess is really three disparate games in one: a repetitive early game that has been studied and scripted to death, a fascinating and hugely variable middle game with beautiful tactics, and a degenerate and unsatisfying late game that consistently devolves into obsessive, finicky patterns of goading/avoiding a drawn game.

The main issue is that in Chess, the difference between an overwhelming advantage and a hopeless, insulting loss can be a single square of a single move by a single piece. Looks like you’ve been checked! You’ve got three options here: King to G8, you’re maintaining your over-200 centipawn advantage, nice work! King on G7, it’s a perfect draw somehow (trust me on this). King to G6, that’s a mate in eight you idiot! Tread lightly, and remember, have fun!

Blunders in Chess are just punished with such ruthless, binary decisiveness that a good game is measured far more by the absence of mistakes than the presence of skill, and my mind simply doesn't enjoy that type of play environment. I need my board games (even my combinatorial abstracts) to provide me interesting lines of play that are wider than a razor’s edge.

There is something to be said for a board game having such a monumental cultural influence, but I dislike a lot of the surrounding “mythology” that comes with that: the idea that Chess is some final frontier of intellectualism, a hallowed, even ground where great minds come to test and wrestle one another as equals. But if you step back and really look at Chess the game and not Chess the cultural concept, it reveals itself to be a fairly inelegant, even downright silly abstract game:

These pieces move one space forward. Except on their first move of the game, then it can be two. And also they only capture diagonally. What’s that? No there’s no other piece that has different movement and capture rules, why would there be? Oh and also don’t forget that if your opponent tries to pull that “two-spaces-on-the-first-move” trick and your piece is in this one specific spot next to it, you’re allowed to just go ahead and capture it retroactively as it “passed through” the space. No of course you can’t do that with other pieces that could have captured something “during” a move, why would you?

Oh and also remember that sort of important king piece? Well checking him early was too good and made our games boring, so we invented this zany little house rule where you can tuck him away in a corner of the board by moving him exactly two spaces horizontally in either direction and putting the rook that’s on the side he moved towards on the space directly opposite of where he ends up! No, you can’t ever move two pieces at once except for this…why do you keep asking questions like that? But there can’t be anything in the way when you do the flip and you can’t do it if he’s in check or would retroactively be in check during any part of the “move” and you can’t do it if the king has moved already this game, which you’ll just have to remember manually, which sort of goes against the complete-information core of Chess but you'll figure it out!

Now that we’re talking about it, the end of our games were pretty boring too, we just ended up having our dinky little pawns on the board and our king. How is anyone supposed to win with just that? So we made it so those puny pawns upgrade into mega-badass queens when they get to the end of the board for some reason. No of course we’re not gonna provide the components to accommodate the possibility of having duplicate queens on the board in your color, if you manage to get another queen the game is basically over, there’s no need. Unless of course you foolishly place your queen on C3 instead of C4, collapsing a hundred moves of perfect play into a devastating stalemate instead of a win, but simply don’t do that you imbecile!

Does it sound like I’m bitter? Maybe I am a little. Chess just has such a monolithic place in the western canon, and I was raised to believe that this was a pure, elegant, ancient test of skill, something that clever people flock to and are good at. But it’s just a fiddly, only kind-of-old abstract game that is a Frankenstein of mechanics and gotchas accumulated over the centuries to make it not completely rote. Even then, white still has a non-negligible advantage, a huge chunk of high-level games end in draws (yuck), and the number one indicator of success in Chess isn't your tenacity or your experience playing games in general, it's how much you've studied Chess. With all that’s been done in the abstract genre in the last few decades alone, I see little reason to keep throwing myself against this particular, much-loved wall.

The big problem with chess is that there are all those pieces, each with their own move-set, attacking at least 4 different directions, able to move any number of spaces along those directions, all jammed and twisted together in the center of the board. The human mind (without extensive training) can't comprehend it all. Chess games are filled with lamentations of "OHHHH you can hit that piece?!" "OHH I didn't see that!" "OHH I forgot you could attack there!" That is bad game design. If it was made today, publishers would turn it down.

I actually kind of hate chess. There's no appeal to it for a casual player, because the person who wants to play you is far from casual and will destroy you every time. That person is my husband, who watches chess match analysis videos in his leisure time.

If someone asks me to play chess, it's probably because they like Chess, which means they're probably an experienced player, which means I'll most likely lose. Pass.

The 0% variance in Chess makes the game too dependent on rote learning. A competitive game is entertaining, because it expects of you to adapt to your opponent's play. That's where Chess shines - if you play with someone at your level, that is. If not, one of you will simply have memorized more situations than the other, and they lose out of pure inexperience. Chess is the definition of git-gud mentality, and I don't play to get good at something - I just play to have fun with friends and family. If I get good at a game, it's an unfortunate side effect which narrows how many people I can have a fun, balanced game with.

I feel it is simply my responsibility as a legitimate game designer and someone who understands and appreciates games on a higher level than the swaths of people who have haphazardly rated it a ten despite having little to no familiarity with other games. I could go on a lengthy diatribe about its various shortcomings but I wont. New games are better. Game design is a science and like any science it become more refined over time. If the current market doesn't reflect this then it reflects only on the lack of refinement of popular designers. Oh and Chess is a game from the dark ages. Its time to move on.
Pretty much every mechanic I hate in a game: pure information, direct conflict, no theme, no variability in set-up, and a large learning curve to play well. No thanks.

I played chess in primary school because that's what smart kids did. However, I liked the puzzle aspect of chess more than I did the game itself. I was never able to fathom nor appreciate the finer points of chess strategy (strength of 2 bisshops are stronger than one bisshop and a knight, or that a rook and a bishop are more powerful than a queen) and so abandoned the game when there were no more puzzles left for me to solve.

There are more modern variants of the game which tone down its depth, and align more with the amount of time I have at my disposal, as well as the interest level of my opponents. Hive comes to mind, for example. But also a completely different abstract game altogether, like for example Backgammon.

I admire the game from a distance, but Chess is kind of impenetrable and not exactly enjoyable. I have played a game here and there over the deacades but I have little interest in memorizing patterns and missed the window for becoming some brainiac Chess Grandmaster.

I enjoy chess quite a bit, but it is hard to play a casual game, it seems most people are not interested at all or they are some hypercompetitive chess nerd, either type of opponent takes the fun out of the game. The best thing about chess is the sense of scholarship -- it has been in play in the West for centuries and generations have devoted significant time to studying it and perfecting its play, fueling its growth into a full-blown sport where the top tier players retain celebrity status.

The interesting dynamic about chess is that it builds up to a crescendo with the initial opening maneuvers giving way to a blood bath which seems to indeed evoke the feeling of a climactic battle.

Unfortunately chess is a deeply unforgiving game, and all the fancy maneuvering to assure interlocking defenses and mutually supporting units falls apart with a single blunder, which is almost always the way someone loses in the game at the amateur levels, as opposed to being defeated by superior strategy. To get the most enjoyment out of the game, your opponent needs to play their best without inadvertently triggering these blunders, but it rarely happens.

You will never catch me being excited to play a game of chess. Maybe it's because I played it so extensively when I was younger, but I'm so tired of it. I just get this feeling, almost like a reminder, that I should be playing something else; that I've moved on from Chess and onto better things. I know that Chess slander is very common in this hobby, but I kind of get it. My biggest problem with Chess is that it is too hard to see where you are in the game (if you have not studied Chess). Without studying the game, it's nearly impossible to know what a winning position looks like, or how to get there. So most of the game, you are constantly stuck making choices that have no weight or feel very unsatisfying, because your goals and personal ambitions don't exist.

After getting in this hobby, there's just so many other games that give me a lot more joy. And I truly don't believe that it's this perfect game that a lot people seem to claim it as. There's better strategy games than Chess now. It's over 500 years old for gods sake.

Many, many books and videos available, but all are by third parties and not the development team -- in fact, there are so many thousands of companies selling "knockoffs" and weird designs that it's hard to find genuine original game equipment (see photos) -- people can't even agree on what color the pieces should be. There are many more contemporary and far better abstract strategy games available. Time has passed this one by.

• Simple rules with deep strategic complexity

Cons :

Conclusion :
A timeless classic suited for enthusiasts willing to invest time in deep learning.

Un juego que no necesita que le cambien ni una coma, que lleva jugandose siglos, con reglas sencillas pero una profundidad que posibilita la dedicación completa de una vida para dominar, con torneos federaciones y movimiento por todo el mundo y cientos de miles de jugadores diarios. Conozco a muchas personas que nunca le concederán el crédito a semejante currículum, argumentarán que es un juego donde conocer las aperturas te da una superioridad insalvable, que no merece gastar el tiempo solamente para igualar esa desventaja. Desconocen que en el ajedrez lo más importante es la táctica, el juego medio, el desarrollo de las piezas, elaborar una estrategia que permita a cada movimiento contrarestar el del contrario, permitiendo un enorme margen a la creatividad. Todo esto deja las aperturas y finales de partida como un trámite técnico importante, pero no imprescindible.
Además hay un concepto que no quisiera dejar de destacar. La belleza en el ajedrez es algo que solo he podido disfrutar en su máximo esplendor en este juego. Y no me refiero solo a la partida casera aficionada donde consigues una buena combinación, sino a los miles de partidas que ha dejado la historia, que están convenientemente registradas y analizadas y que han tenido momentos de genialidad a la altura de los más grandes logros de la creatividad humana.

I grew up with chess, playing on some of the first chess machines, and occasionally with friends. I'm glad my kids have taken a liking to it too. Alternating between chess, Shogi, and Xiangqi, I've developed a love for all three, and my son will happily play any of them with me any night. I'm really lucky. My daughter fancies a game too, sometimes, and, strangely, doesn't get too upset about losing. With her, we sometimes play "pretend castle" after the game. As you can maybe tell, i'm not a serious chess player, and I'm sure by the time he is 10, my son will be able to beat me regularly (he's 8 and still gives me a good challenge). Chess has this image of geniuses playing it attached to it, but it can very much be enjoyed as a board game like any other. I play it like I would play, say, a game of Scythe.

Strategy: a lower rating means the game is shallow in depth, or heavy luck is involved to win. A higher rating means the game is rich in depth, has a good skill/luck balance, and is almost always won through better skill.
Speed: a lower rating means the game drags on, or not much happens when it’s not your turn. A higher rating means time flies when playing this game, or that things continue happening even when it’s not your turn. (The overall length of a game is not what is being rated, though this may contribute to the rating.)
Freshness: a lower rating means the game usually feels the same and stagnant. A higher rating means the game constantly feels different and new.
Ease of learning: a lower rating means the rules are complex or cumbersome for most people. A higher rating means the rules can be grasped by most without a huge time input.
Theme: a lower rating means the vibe isn’t the most compelling, or that the mechanics don’t thematically relate to the game’s world. A higher rating means the vibe is beautiful and fascinating, or that the mechanics thematically relate to the game’s world.

Each category is weighted differently based on how much it matters to me for the overall rating. For example, I believe the level of skill and luck involved and the speed of the game contributes more to the overall enjoyment of a game than the theme of a game or its initial ease of learning, but others may disagree.
